narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: virtual discussion
recorded lecture + live virtual lecture
Combination of live virtual lecture + in-person lectures + in-virtual discussion sections

Although lectures were presented live on Zoom (with an in-person component for some professors' lectures), many students chose to view the recorded Zoom lectures on their own time. Very few students seemed to have attended the in-person lectures in Marsh -- maybe 3 maximum. This lecture course used to be powered completely by chalk talks, so I 100% understand why some professors opted to go to Marsh in person anyway, and I appreciate the flexibility that was offered to students in terms of how they wanted to learn the material. But, opening Marsh just for 0-3 people seemed a little extraneous otherwise.
Virtual or live lectures (depending on the comfort of the professors and public health situation) that were all recorded.
Mostly live virtual  lectures with some in-person lectures
Mandatory Section - synchronous.
Many of the lecturers offered an in-person session in YSB, and the lectures were also recorded. There were weekly, mandatory discussion sections as well.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Deeper knowledge of the immune system

I now have a basic broad understanding of the immune mechanisms by which our bodies defend from pathogens like bacteria and viruses, and how certain autoimmune, inflammatory, or infectious diseases take ahold. This research course also developed my abilities to compare across multiple signaling pathways and concepts that synthesize several lectures. I also got to learn a bit about each professor's research area of interest, since the lectures were done on a rotation. These basic fundamentals will be invaluable to any graduate student in IBIO, and also any undergrad writing their senior thesis in an IBIO lab.
Immune system overview
Anything and everything you could possibly want to know about the immune system!
Topics in innate and adaptive immune system

The course offered a broad overview of the immune system but wasn't just surface level. Offered a good level of detail on essential concepts. Gained fundamental knowledge of all facets of the immune system and immunological techniques.
I learned a ton about the immune system. Just a bunch of facts - but tbh facts are what we need to know for grad school/med school so 10/10!
Immunology skills and knowledge.
I was taught an overview of the innate and adaptive immune systems, how they interact, and more specific information about how autoreactivity is avoided/B and T cells develop and migrate.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Please remove discussion section, not a good use of time

The lectures themselves were great for the most part. Some professors went into way way way too much detail than what the exams asked for, and that was still fine. I learned a lot, which was a huge strength. Now the weaknesses: what was really annoying was that we took the midterm on October 28th. But because the way this course is designed, there was not much oversight on the TAs by a specific prof (at least I dont think because if there was, Im not sure that this would have happen), and it literally took them until December 1st to give us back our grades. That was exactly TEN DAYS before the final exam. I have never taken a class at Yale where it took the TAs THAT long to grade midterms. Considering that the midterm is 30% and final is 40%, this delay wasnt okay. Also note, by this point in time, we had grades for two HW assignments, so we only knew where 13.33% of our total grade stood before December 1st. And because of this, there was barely any time (literally ten days only) to improve study methods and/or fix what we were doing if it was not working. Aside from that, the exam questions, at least the essays, were fairly broad and they took several points off for not including minor facts (in relation to mechanisms) that they did not explicitly ask for. And for quite a few questions, points were taken off without providing any feedback at all.

The course covers a lot of material, and takes advantage of the many amazing faculty in the IBIO department in order to do so. That being said, the professors' lecture materials don't seem to have been coordinated well among each other, and there was quite a bit of redundancy and overlap. Although this helped to strengthen certain key concepts, it also got very repetitive by the fourth time we learned the nitty gritty details about the 3 signal hypothesis. On the flip side, sometimes professors believed we learned about a certain concept (such as AIRE selection) before the corresponding lecture had been taught. I also think that the course midterm (though not the final) seemed to emphasize research-based questions and experimental design, which was okay for people who had research experience in IBIO but probably very difficult to answer otherwise because the lecture did not spend time introducing how experimental thinking worked beyond making us read the appendix on immunology tools in the first week of class. Spending a little more time across the semester (and not just in the 1st discussion section) on experimental design, maybe in discussion sections, would be very helpful.
So many professors made learning choppy. Hard to understand how topics related.

While the lectures were individually really interesting and the professors were incredibly knowledgeable, I feel like more could have been done to tie all the disparate topics together or give a more high-level overview of immune function. Felt piecemeal at times.
Topics are taught by experts in their fields; weakness was grading, which seemed a little harsh in my opinion given that this is an introductory course

The course covers many important topics in immunobiology, but is incredibly packed. While you get many leaders in their own fields lecturing, by virtue of them being at the cutting edge, they often contradict each other when they all talk about overlapping topics, which creates a lot of confusion. The frequent switching of lecturers and the multitude of presenting methods was also incredibly disorienting. This was made worse by video and audio issues, as well as the poor handwriting of those professors who refused to just make slides (those who did usually did not post them), which just made learning the complicated concepts of this course a complete headache.

The course was for the most part conceptually well organized. I liked the flow from innate to adaptive immunity with special topics at the end which required knowledge of the entire semester's content to understand. Some professors adapted to the online format better than others. Overall, it was really interesting to learn about some concepts from the people themselves who made discoveries in the field.

Weakness - grading was unnecessarily harsh at times. It is just a brutal class because there is so much to learn. Only take if you need a primer for some future courses (aka: grad school or medical school)

Strength - You do learn a lot. And the immune system is awesome. But if you go in knowing nothing/unexcited about the topic, you're not going to have a great time.

Strengths were the breadth of knowledge we got. Weaknesses include sometimes lecturers would repeat the same things we already learned in another lecture in depth, and there was little practice material given for exams.

A strength of the course is how topics are continuously reinforced despite the variety of lecturers such that you feel that you have a solid understanding by the end of the course. Another strength was how interesting and topical some of the lectures on immunotherapy and vaccination were.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall good adaptation

There was not enough time allotted for the midterm -- it would have been difficult to finish the midterm in 1 hour, and yet 1 hour also had to include the uploading steps for the scanned pages. That being said, I was thankful that the TAs walked through how midterm uploading worked and made us practice during section. I do wish that the midterm were graded more quickly though, since the feedback on the midterm could have helped me to practice or better focus my studying during the semester to adjust my thinking modalities for the final exam. Also, not all professors were willing to upload lecture slides, which made reviewing material a little difficult. Midterm feedback was also pretty unclear unless people reached out explicitly to the TAs.
Could improve with office hours.
Recorded lectures were a big help!
Recorded lectures were so important mostly because the lectures were often unclear or the material was so dense. You needed to watch them multiple times just to understand what was going on.

Recorded lecture + synchronous section was amazing. The TAs this year all put in mounds of effort to help us out. Also open note tests were fantastic - but I KNOW people cheated and it makes me angry. Oh well
It seemed like the class was geared toward covid fine.

The lecture recordings were helpful, but some instructors did not post slides/pictures of their lecture, so your notes had to suffice. However, from my understanding, this is actually an improvement from previous semesters during which only chalk talks were allowed and no slides were posted. To help compensate for this, there was a course packet with up to pages of material on each lecture that I found incredibly useful for homework and exam purposes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it's a lot of content but good crash course
Only if you're okay with not knowing where your grade stands until almost the end (ie. ten days before the final is when we got our midterm exam grades back). Personally, I wasn't.

Definitely a good course if you have a vested interest in immunology or work in an IBIO research lab, but I think it would be overwhelming and very difficult to conceptualize for anyone who is not as interested or is encountering some of the material for the first time. If you're an MCDB senior and looking for a 350+ course, take this if you like immunology, but think about other seminars if you do research in something else (eg. pure genetics).
Yes, great class

If you're an undergrad genuinely interested in learning about immunology (and some cancer biology), there's probably no better class. Otherwise, be warned that this class is far from an automatic A. You'll need to put in the work to learn everything!
The material covered is very useful.

Take it if you're genuinely interested, but be warned. The material is incredibly interesting, but marred by very disorganized administration and repeated runs by different lecturers who clearly did not communicate with each other, which created a lot of confusion.

Yes, the content was very interesting to someone who loves immunology. The course was definitely challenging due to the sheer amount of content and the level of detail you are expected to memorize it at. Only take if you are really interested in immunology.
Only if you need it (for BS/MS) or you need the knowledge for research/med school/grad school. Otherwise I would take a more entry-level class like the one taught by Prof. Kavathas.
I think it was okay. It can be helpful if you are doing immunobio research.

I would recommend this course to another student because of the interesting and important material, but it is key to stay on top of the material independently since the discussion sections and homework were low-key and infrequent respectively. This isn't unusual for an upper level course, but the exam took about a month to be graded, so there is a lot of anxiety if you aren't confident in your performance.
